reasoning: The critique targets Counterargument 7 (“strongest link” / multiple routes), which is only one of many independent reasons the position gives for discounting compute bottlenecks; refuting it would not strongly undermine the overall case, so centrality is low (~0.2). Within that targeted point, the critique is fairly strong: it argues the ‘one route needs to work’ move is too permissive, lacks a principled obstacle-selection rule, and needs positive evidence that at least one route has favorable substitutability, which substantially undercuts CA7 as stated. Most claims are correct (the objection is largely about non-discriminating possibility arguments), though the ‘proves too much’ framing slightly overstates by analogy to alignment/regulation. The critique is clear, focused on a single issue, and contains little to no fluff. Overall impact on the position is limited mainly because CA7 is not a load-bearing part of the position’s conclusion.
title: The strongest link framing could dismiss any obstacle without principled criteria
